courses.name: Introduction to Health: Determinants of Health & Health Care (formerly UNI209H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A multidisciplinary approach to understanding perspectives in health, health equity, and primary health care. Themes include critical discussion of the measurements of health outcomes and the socioeconomic and political factors that affect health, including neglected and marginalized populations in Canada and globally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health: Determinants of Health & Health Care (formerly UNI209H1)

courses.name: Health Policy in Canada (formerly UNI211H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to health policy in Canada, with a particular focus on the social determinants of health, and on how to improve health through policy advocacy. Examines the policy making process in the Canadian context, and the development of health policy in Canada. Explores current debates about health issues
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Policy in Canada (formerly UNI211H1)

courses.name: Introduction to Research Methods in Health Studies (formerly UNI250H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Offers students in Health Studies a basic understanding of research design and data collection on health topics. Also assesses the usefulness of research and data collection in the formation of health policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Research Methods in Health Studies (formerly UNI250H1)

courses.name: Special Topics in Health Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: The specific content of this course will vary from one year to another, depending on the availability of particular health researchers and scholars. Specific course information will be available on the Health Studies website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies/.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Studies I

courses.name: Aging and Health (formerly UNI308H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides an understanding of the interface between health and aging, and how to maintain wellness in a rapidly aging population. Examines theories of aging, the meaning of health in old age, myths about the health of Canadas older people, and emerging national and international responses to aging populations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Aging and Health (formerly UNI308H1)

courses.name: Special Topics in Health Studies II (formerly UNI309H1)

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Indigenous Health and Healing in the Six Nations

cmCourseInfo.description: The specific content of this course will vary from one year to another, depending on the availability of particular health researchers and scholars. Specific course information will be available on the Health Studies website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies/.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Health Studies II (formerly UNI309H1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Departmental approval is required for enrolment. To apply, you must submit in the application form located on the Health Studies website at: www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies and email it to Prof. Sarah Wakefield at: sarah.wakefield@utoronto.ca. Once approved the department will enrol you into the course. Please ensure you reserve a space on your timetable for this course. There are no prerequisites, and the recommended preparation for this course is at least 9.0 FCEs. Distribution Requirement Status: This is a Social Science course. The course will be limited in size: Majors and Specialists in Health Studies and Indigenous Studies and Indigenous students from any discipline will have first priority for spaces. NB: Each student is required to pay a portion of the cost of the trip amounting to $450 per student, in addition to the regular course tuition fee. The amount includes costs of transportation, accommodation, meals, and activities throughout the time at Six Nations. Some students will be eligible for bursaries to partially cover this cost. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC165, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca

courses.name: Critical Health Policy (formerly UNI310H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical, in-depth exploration of contemporary health and social issues. Political, social and economic forces at play in Canadian society are examined in relation to specific health issues and policies, in order to understand general societal and system dynamics of evolution and change, and to identify implications for reform efforts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Health Policy (formerly UNI310H1)

courses.name: Population Health (formerly UNI330H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Extends students understanding of population-based strategies of health promotion in Canada. Topics include: variations in health status as affected by population patterns, class, gender, ethnicity, employment, and family composition; major causes of morbidity and mortality; the concept of "community health", opportunities and constraints facing public policy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Population Health (formerly UNI330H1)

courses.name: Health Research & Practice (formerly UNI350Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: For students enrolled in the Health Studies Specialist and Major programs. Students engage in activities that will prepare them for independent research and practicum projects. Includes, but not limited to, sessions on topic selection and program development, finding a supervisor, ethics and professionalism, formulating a grant proposal.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Research & Practice (formerly UNI350Y1)

courses.name: Epidemiology (formerly UNI373H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to the principles and methods of epidemiology. Emphasis on descriptive methods and study design. Computational techniques, measurement problems, and issues that surround the drawing of inferences from area-level or other aggregate data will be discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Epidemiology (formerly UNI373H1)

courses.name: Health Studies Practicum

cmCourseInfo.description: Individual field placement with a health-related institution or organization, in which the student applies theory and skills to specific projects and/or tasks. Culminates in an oral and written report. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Studies Practicum

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For 'E' indicator courses: College approval is required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC165, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Advanced Special  Topics in Health Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: The specific content of this course will vary from one year to another, depending on the availability of particular health researchers and scholars. Specific course information will be available on the Health Studies website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies/.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Special  Topics in Health Studies I

courses.name: Advanced Special  Topics in Health Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: The specific content of this course will vary from one year to another, depending on the availability of particular health researchers and scholars. Specific course information will be available on the Health Studies website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/healthstudies/.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Special  Topics in Health Studies I

courses.name: Case Studies in Health Policy (formerly UNI408H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Analyses the formation and implementation of health policy through the use of case studies. Each case deals with a substantive health policy issue. Using case studies, students will learn to understand and analyze the processes by which public policies are formed, and perform comparisons of policy alternatives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies in Health Policy (formerly UNI408H1)

courses.name: Political Economy of Health (formerly UNI411H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the production and distribution of health and illness within and across populations. A political economy approach is used to better understand the fundamental origins of health inequalities, the political action that is required to tackle them, and the obstacles that hinder the possibilities for such action.
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Economy of Health (formerly UNI411H1)

courses.name: Health & Pharmaceuticals (formerly UNI440H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical examination of drug development, including the role of health professionals and the pharmaceutical industry in researching, testing, marketing, licensing, and evaluating pharmaceutical drugs. Topics include the differing needs for drug development, evaluation and dispensing in lower income countries, and potential conflicts of interest in drug development.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health & Pharmaceuticals (formerly UNI440H1)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: UNI440H1, UNI330H1 (Health & Pharmaceuticals) taken prior to 2010-11

courses.name: Undergraduate Health Research Project (formerly UNI450Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Students engage in a specific research project during their last two years within the program. Student will prepare an undergraduate thesis by the end of the course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Undergraduate Health Research Project (formerly UNI450Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For 'E' indicator courses: College approval is required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC165, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Independent Research in Health Studies (formerly UNI451Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This two-semester course designation will permit students to gain academic credit for health studies pursued independently under the supervision of a University of Toronto faculty member; or to participate in an ongoing health research project under the joint supervision of the projects Principal Investigator and the Director of the Health Studies Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Health Studies (formerly UNI451Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

courses.name: The Nature of International Health (formerly UNI464H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the historical, ideological, economic, political, and organizational factors that shape the theory and practice of international health (IH). Students will be encouraged to critically examine some of the central tensions embedded in this field.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Nature of International Health (formerly UNI464H1)

courses.name: Independent Research in Health Studies (formerly UNI480H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This one-semester course will permit students to gain academic credit for health studies pursued independently, or to participate in an ongoing health research project, under the supervision of a University of Toronto faculty member. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research in Health Studies (formerly UNI480H1)
